case_vignette: A 60-year-old healthy female presents with a rash affecting the areas under the bilateral breasts ongoing for the past three months. She states the rash worsens with sweat and humidity. She denies any new topical products applied to the area. She has tried over the counter hydrocortisone without significant relief. She denies any personal and family history of psoriasis or atopic dermatitis. Examination reveals multiple bright red flat topped poorly demarcated papules coalescing into large red plaques with satellite papules and few pustules under the bilateral breasts.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash under both of my breasts that has been there for the past three months.
Have you noticed any itching or pain associated with the rash?
Yes, the rash gets worse with sweat and humidity.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
No, I haven't made any new changes to what I put on my skin or my diet.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been exposed to new environments.
Have you had any family members with similar symptoms?
No, there's no family history of similar skin issues.
Have you had any recent illnesses or infections?
No, I haven't been sick recently.
Have you been taking any medications recently?
I have tried over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream, but it didn't really help.
Have you noticed any changes in your menstrual cycle or hormonal levels?
I haven't noticed any changes in my menstrual cycle or hormones.
Have you noticed any changes in your weight or body composition?
No, my weight has stayed the same.
Have you noticed any changes in your stress levels or sleep patterns?
I haven't noticed any changes in my stress levels or how I've been sleeping.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin texture or appearance?
Yes, I've noticed bright red, flat spots that are merging into larger red areas with some small bumps and a few tiny pustules under my breasts.
Final Diagnosis: Eczema.
